lg.l: The land of the dismal swamp, Dismal swamp. Settlers in the town of Tauranga had been publicly agitating about the “unhealthy” nature of the swampy land near Grey Street since the mid-1870s.
Where death and disease are bred,
The rat, the cat, the frog, and the dog,
Unburied lie in this noisome bog.
And round it are homes so dear,
Where, close to its margin drear
Through the long bright summer’s day,
The sun at work with refulgent rays

Will a score of offensive odours Offensive odours. A letter published in the Bay of Plenty Times in 17 August 1880 complained that “the stench arising from the place is most unpleasant, and may very likely breed a plague.” raise.
And know you this fearful land,
Off Spring Street, from the Strand,
Along Grey Street Spring Street … the Strand … Grey Street. Streets in a central part of Tauranga. a few feet.
Here is the spot so much deplored,
But---where’s the action of the Board? Board. The Town Board acted to fill in the swamp in 1881, but it remained a cause of settler complaint in later years.
